title: 104_hr1497
content: The Act titled "Insurance Tax Fairness and Small Insurance Company Economic Growth Act of 1995" revises the limitation on the deduction of policyholder dividends by mutual life insurance companies. The Act "Insurance Tax Fairness and Small Insurance Company Economic Growth Act of 1995" amends the deduction limitation for policyholder dividends by mutual life insurance companies. The amendment specifies that the deduction for any taxable year shall not exceed 90% of policyholder dividends or 30% of taxable income, with a minimum limitation of $35,000,000. The Act "Insurance Tax Fairness and Small Insurance Company Economic Growth Act of 1995" amends the deduction limitation for policyholder dividends by mutual life insurance companies to not exceed 90% of policyholder dividends or 30% of taxable income, with a minimum limitation of $35,000,000. Additionally, the Act repeals Section 809 of the Code and amends subparagraph (B) of section 807(a)(2) accordingly. The Act "Insurance Tax Fairness and Small Insurance Company Economic Growth Act of 1995" repeals Section 809 of the Code and makes amendments to various sections related to tax-exempt interest and policyholders' share. The effective date for these amendments is for taxable years beginning after December 31, 1994. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1994. These changes do not affect the application of section 809(f) before its repeal for taxable years before January 1, 1995. Additionally, no capital loss from a taxable year after December 31, 1994, can be carried back to a year before January 1, 1995 for life insurance companies subject to the limitation under section 808(b)(2) of the Code. SEC. 3 exempts small life insurance companies from capitalizing specified policy acquisition expenses after December 31, 1994. SEC. 4 states that any revenue increase from the amendments should be used for deficit reduction, tax incentives for small life insurance companies, and programs benefiting children.
